title: na with Tense
goal: Understand how `na` interacts with tense markers.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

na review:

I don't go → ?
This is not good → ?

(Answers: mi na klama, ti na xamgu)

New Material (5-7 min)

na + Tense: Order Matters

The position of na relative to tense changes meaning:

na Before Tense

mi na pu klama

It is not the case that [I went]. (Negates the entire past claim.)

Tense Before na

mi pu na klama

I past-not-go. = In the past, I didn't go. (The negation is within the past context.)

Subtle Difference

Form Reading
mi na pu klama Not true that [I went]
mi pu na klama [I didn't go] in the past

In practice, both often mean "I didn't go," but technically:

  • First: denies the whole past claim
  • Second: affirms a past state of not-going

Examples

mi na pu citka lo plise

It's not true that I ate apples.

mi pu na citka lo plise

In the past, I didn't eat apples.

Practical Advice

For most purposes, mi pu na klama is the natural way to say "I didn't go."

Key Point

Position matters: na pu negates the claim; pu na places negation in the past.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Translate Both Forms

Translate:

  1. It's not true that I went. → ?
  2. I didn't go (in the past). → ?
Answers
  1. mi na pu klama
  2. mi pu na klama

Exercise 2: Identify Meaning

What does each mean?

  1. mi na ba citka
  2. mi ba na citka
  3. mi na ca gunka
Answers
  1. It's not true that I will eat.
  2. I will not eat (in the future).
  3. It's not true that I am working now.

Exercise 3: Real Situations

Translate naturally:

  1. I didn't sleep.
  2. I won't go.
  3. I am not working now.
Answers
  1. mi pu na sipna
  2. mi ba na klama
  3. mi ca na gunka

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "I didn't go." → mi pu na klama
  2. "I won't eat." → mi ba na citka
  3. "I'm not working." → mi ca na gunka

Today's Grammar

Form Meaning
na pu + selbri Not true that [past event]
pu na + selbri In the past, [didn't do]

Summary

You learned how na interacts with tense. Order matters: na pu negates the claim; pu na locates negation in the past.
